channel.title: Sub-atomic Universes
channel.description: this may have been said before but it always interests me - has anyone noticed how an atom can on some levels look like the planets orbiting around a star, you get different atoms with different amounts of electrons and the electrons orbit the the atom in shells so what if these shells were seperated by an asteroid belt like how sections of our solar system are. Also when you get a picture of the universe web it does strangely look like a tissue structure so what if each atom in our body was a solar system and each muscle fibre was its own universe and our solar system is an atom on the muscle fibre of a human?

item.title: Sub-atomic Universes
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“MacaYork, post:5, topic:509460”][quote author=Rix_ link=topic=627703.msg4265823#msg4265823 date=1364044832]
Has anyone really been far even as decided to use even go want to do look more like?
[/quote]

Scientists have been able to use images they have gathered from the hubble etc. to generate ap icture of what they think the universe looks like and the generation shows clusters of galaxies linked in a web like structure[/quote]
As far as I know we do not know nor can we currently understand the topology of the universe. I’m sure we know what the observable universe looks like as far as where what is located, however.

Read full topic

item.title: Sub-atomic Universes
item.dc:creator: @adeathsmckitten adeathsmckitten
item.description:
@adeathsmckitten wrote:

Our Universe could be an atom in an entirely larger and unknown world.

Read full topic

item.title: Sub-atomic Universes
item.dc:creator: @MacaYork MacaYork
item.description:
@MacaYork wrote:

eyeownyew:

In the diagram of the atom, protons are within the Nucleus, electrons are in the rings around the nucleus, and neutrons are within the nucleus, so no. What I’m talking about is matter between planets or electrons.

OK i knew that i just didn’t gather from your post that you meant that there isn’t smaller matter between the electron shells, cheers for clearing that up.

Maybe we just don’t have equipment powerful enough yet to detect something on that microscopic of a scale.

Read full topic

item.title: Sub-atomic Universes
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

In the diagram of the atom, protons are within the Nucleus, electrons are in the rings around the nucleus, and neutrons are within the nucleus, so no. What I’m talking about is matter between planets or electrons.

Read full topic

item.title: Sub-atomic Universes
item.dc:creator: @MacaYork MacaYork
item.description:
@MacaYork wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:9, topic:509460”]I believe theses is the plural of the word thesis

But yes, there is a relationship between the images, and scientists have found that fascinating for years; however, there is no possible way that an atom is actually a solar system simply because there cannot be small matter within an atom as there is small (relationally) matter within our solar system (asteroids, etc). Also, electrons move much faster than planets, but I suppose that counter-argument is disproven with the Theory of Relativity…[/quote]

Are protons and neutrons not classed as smaller matter?

Read full topic

item.title: Sub-atomic Universes
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

I believe theses is the plural of the word thesis

But yes, there is a relationship between the images, and scientists have found that fascinating for years; however, there is no possible way that an atom is actually a solar system simply because there cannot be small matter within an atom as there is small (relationally) matter within our solar system (asteroids, etc). Also, electrons move much faster than planets, but I suppose that counter-argument is disproven with the Theory of Relativity…

Read full topic

item.title: Sub-atomic Universes
item.dc:creator: @MacaYork MacaYork
item.description:
@MacaYork wrote:

I was tired when i posted originally so I’m going to clarify my point with pictures;

Universe Web: http://www.lsw.uni-heidelberg.de/users/mcamenzi/images/Cosmic_web.jpg
Muscle Tissue: http://cache2.allpostersimages.com/p/LRG/30/3040/9DPBF00Z/posters/cardiac-muscle-tissue-pseudocolored-micrograph.jpg
These aren’t the best comparisons but here is a decent comparison to re-iterate my point about electrons and the solar system;
Solar System: http://neography.com/_base/uploads/solar_system.jpg
Atom: http://itc.gsw.edu/faculty/speavy/spclass/chemistry/atoms.3.gif

My original point was the similarities in both of these pairs of pictures.
What if an atom was a scaled down solar system and our solar system itself was an atom in a giant human being, if you do a quick google search you can find many thesis (not sure on the plural version of the word) on atoms containing universes of their own.

Hopefully that clarifies my original post and I apologize for my lack of grammar in it.

Read full topic

item.description:

Scientists have been able to use images they have gathered from the hubble etc. to generate ap icture of what they think the universe looks like and the generation shows clusters of galaxies linked in a web like structure[/quote]
Bad answer Maca, his sentence made no sense whatsoever. He was making fun of the OP because his post made very little sense.

item.title: Sub-atomic Universes
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

those web-like structures came from when the universe was still opaque to light and before elements etc could form, the web-like structures came from different rates of cooling I believe resulting in areas where more elements were formed than other, forming stars and galaxies that generally stuck to the structure

the cosmic microwave background is an incredibly cool picture I think

Read full topic

@Ashi wrote:

I’m pretty sure everything with a mass has its own gravitational energy even if it’s an unnoticeable amount. I guess our body’s work a bit like the universe if that’s how you want to picture it.
